questions.text: Ina child with Tetralogy of fallot with fever and diarrhea, which of the following is the surest sign of cyanotic spell:

options.label: A
options.text: Arterial Oxygen Saturation Of Less than 75%

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Nelson 20th Ed/2212; Park’s pediatric cardiology 6th Ed Explanation: Cyanotic spell (also known as tet spell) is a common complication of tetralogy of fallot in first year of life. It is characterized by worsening of cyanosis (with arterial SpO2 falling below 45-50%), hyperventilation and faint or absent pulmonary ejection systolic murmur. A child with a loud murmur initially, if presents with rapid breathing and cyanosis, absence of murmur is a useful clinical clue for cyanotic spell in that child. Remember: Hepatomegaly, basal crepitations and S3 gallop rhythm are signs of CCF in child

questions.text: A mother comes with her 3 months child asking the physician if she can give cereals to her child.What problem can this lead to in her child?

options.label: A
options.text: Allergy Due To The Food Content

questions.correct_answer: A. Allergy Due To The Food Content

questions.text: A 6 year old man child comes with complaint of bed wetting. the child is dry during the day and problem is only at night. Growth and development of the child was normal. Urine Microscopy Is normal and Urine Specific Gravity Is 1.020. How Will You manage:

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure The parents and follow up after 6 months

questions.correct_answer: A. Reassure The parents and follow up after 6 months
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Points to remember:
  • • Points to remember:
  • • Bed alarm is more successful than drug therapy. Desmopressin is preferred over Imipramine Oral desmopressin is preferred over nasal desmopressin
  • • Bed alarm is more successful than drug therapy.
  • • Desmopressin is preferred over Imipramine
  • • Oral desmopressin is preferred over nasal desmopressin

questions.text: A Child Who Was Normal At Birth develops chronic liver failure and muscle weakness at 3 months of age.of investigation serumglucoseislowalong with ketoacidosis and decreased pH.ALT and AST are raised.Blood Lactate And Uric Acid Levels Are Normal.Intravenous Glucagon Given For meal raises the blood glucose level but does not raise glucose when given after an overnight fast. Liver Biopsy Shows Increased Glycogen in liver. Which Is The Enzyme likely to be defective in this child.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Features to remember for solving MCQs:
  • • Ketotic hypoglycaemia with liver involvement in the form of transaminitis Deficiency of debranching enzyme Absence of lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia (which are common in Von gerke disease) Liver biopsy shows increased glycogen IV glucagon within 2-3 hr of meals improves blood glucose, but that given after overnight fasting/beyond 6-8 hr of meal doesn’t improve blood glucose Dietary therapy is recommended
  • • Ketotic hypoglycaemia with liver involvement in the form of transaminitis
  • • Deficiency of debranching enzyme
  • • Absence of lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia (which are common in Von gerke disease)
  • • Liver biopsy shows increased glycogen
  • • IV glucagon within 2-3 hr of meals improves blood glucose, but that given after overnight fasting/beyond 6-8 hr of meal doesn’t improve blood glucose
  • • Dietary therapy is recommended

questions.text: Whichis the most common congenital abnormality in baby of diabetic women:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • As a system, CVS >CNS As a group of anomalies, Neural tube defects are most common As a single disease, VSD is most common congenital anomaly Most specific anomaly is Caudal regression syndrome Most specific cardiac anomaly is TGA
  • • As a system, CVS >CNS
  • • As a group of anomalies, Neural tube defects are most common
  • • As a single disease, VSD is most common congenital anomaly
  • • Most specific anomaly is Caudal regression syndrome
  • • Most specific cardiac anomaly is TGA

questions.text: A 4year old childi s admitted in the ward with pneumonia and is on ventilation.He Develops Sudden progressive respiratory distress syndrome.The Following Chest x ray was recorded. What will you do Next:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: See the CXR. It is showing hyperinflation (8-9 I/C spaces are visible bilaterally). Development of hyperinflation in a child on ventilator suggests Iatrogenic hyperinflation as a complication due to high PEEP and can lead to pulmonary edema and progressive respiratory distress. Decreasing the ventilatory settings with focus on PaO2 and PaCO2 helps in improvement.

questions.text: Which of these medicines taken during pregnancy is responsible for the defect seen in the child below?
Palivizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody. For which of the following conditions has it been approved for?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Respiratory syncytial virus Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/2048 Explanation: Reduction in the severity and incidence of acute bronchiolitisbecause of RSV is possible through the administration of pooledhyperimmune RSV intravenous immunoglobulin and palivizumab, anintramuscular monoclonal antibody to the RSV F protein, before andduring RSV season. Palivizumab should be considered for infantsyounger than 2 yr of age with chronic lung disease, a history of prematurity,and some forms of congenital heart disease

questions.text: A 2-month-old child was brought to the subcenter by his mother with complaints of fever for two days. Weight of the child is 2kg. On examination, the child is restless and irritable, skin pinch went back in 2 seconds, oral mucosa is dry and eyes were sunken. There were ten pustules on his forehead. What should be done at the subcenter?

options.label: A
options.text: Refer to higher centre with mother giving frequent sips of ORS

options.label: B
options.text: Immediately admit the child, give IV fluids and then refer to higher center

options.label: C
options.text: Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center

options.label: D
options.text: Send child home with few packets of ORS and call after 3 days.

questions.correct_answer: C. Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center Ref: IMNCI guidelines, Ghai8/e, IAP Textbook of Pediatrics Explanation: This is a child with fever, 10 pustules, some dehydration. Any symptomatic febrile child with 10 or more pustules should be assumed to have systemic sepsis. This child needs first dose of antibiotic and started on ORS, followed by immediate referral to higher center for admission (We cannot admit in a subcenter). Among options given, C is the best possible answer (although not the ideal answer)

questions.text: A child presented at 2 years of age with delayed motor development, mental retardation and finger biting. He was normal at birth. He subsequently develops cerebral palsy arthritis and dies due to renal failure at age of 25 years. What is the likely enzyme deficiency implicated?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • HGPRT deficiency Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/746 Explanation: The child has cognitive delay, self-mutilation, CNS dysfunction and renal failure (probably due to hyperuricemia), which are suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND) is a rare X-linked disorder of purine metabolism that results from HGPRT deficiency.

questions.text: A neonate on routine examination at birth was found to have hepatomegaly. Rest of the examination was essentially unremarkable. On investigations, Anti-CMV antibodies were found to be positive. What sequelae in later life is the child at risk of?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Sensorineural hearing loss Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/1593 Explanation:The clinical findings of infants with symptomatic congenitalCMV infections can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes,jaundice, and in some cases microcephaly. Because hearing loss isthe most common long-term sequela associated with congenital CMV infection, the failure of an infant to pass a newborn hearing screeningexam should raise the possibility of congenital CMV infection.

questions.text: A neonate presented with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body with hypoplasia of all limbs. An MRI of the brain revealed diffuse cerebral atrophy. An ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis. Which of these tests is most likely to show a positive result in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Anti-VZV antibody Ref: Nelson 20th Ed/1582 Explanation: The congenital varicella syndrome is characterized by cicatricial skin scarring in a zoster-like distribution; limb hypoplasia; and abnormalities of the neurologic system (e.g., microcephaly, cortical atrophy, seizures, and mental retardation), eye (e.g., chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, and cataracts), renal system (e.g., hydroureter and hydronephrosis), and autonomic nervous system (neurogenic bladder, swallowing dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia). Low birthweight is common among infants with congenital varicella syndrome.

questions.text: What should be the ideal temperature in delivery room?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • 25-28 degree C Ref: WHOThermal protection of Newborn guidelines Explanation: As per WHO guidelines on thermal management in neonates, the delivery room temperature recommended is 25-28 degrees Celsius (77.0-82.4 degrees Fahrenheit).

questions.text: In which of the diseases is the following appearance of calves seen in a child?
Ponderal index is:

options.label: A
options.text: Head circumference to abdominal circumference ratio

options.label: B
options.text: Mid-upper arm circumference to head circumference ratio

options.label: C
options.text: Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters

options.label: D
options.text: Square root of height in feet by weight in grams

questions.correct_answer: C. Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Weight in kilograms by cube of height in meters Ref: Ghai 7/e pg 109; CPDT Explanation: PI is ratio of weight in kg divided by cube of height in meters. It is used to classify neonates into symmetrical and asymmetrical IUGR.

questions.text: Ideal route of drug delivery in neonatal resuscitation is:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Through umbilical vein Ref: NALS 2015 guidelines Explanation: Umbilical venous route is the fastest route to administer drugs in neonatal resuscitation, followed by intraosseous route. Peripheral venous route takes longer time due to difficulty in access and stability of access in neonates in first few hours of life.

questions.text: A neonate presented with jaundice on first day of life.How will you manage?

options.label: A
options.text: Observe only as it is mostly physiological jaundice

options.label: D
options.text: Liver function tests and liver biopsy as it is mostly due to cholestasis

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • As per AIIMS protocol, any baby with serious jaundice, first start phototherapy, then send Total serum bilirubin and decide next course of action.

questions.text: What is the recommended dose of steroids for attaining fetal lung maturity?

options.label: B

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: C. Inj. Dexamethasone 6 mg for 4 doses 12 hours apart

Explanation:

  • • Ref: WHO Update 2016-17 on antenatal pregnancy outcomes
  • • Explanation: As per recent guidelines, Dexamethasone in a dose of 6 mg i.m. for 4 doses is preferred over Betamethasone for fetal lung maturity in preterm labour.

questions.text: A 5-years-old kid brought to the hospital with history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. Mother says he is irritable and drinks water if given. On examination eyes sunken and Skin pinch test- the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment the kid?

options.label: A
options.text: IV Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to higher centre

options.label: B
options.text: Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again next day

options.label: C
options.text: Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre

options.label: D
options.text: No need any treatment. Just observe

questions.correct_answer: B. Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again next day

questions.text: 18 months old kid brought to the hospital with history of breathlessness, fever, cough and cold. On examination respiratory rate was 46/min, there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Give IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre

options.label: B

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding congenital CMV infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Diagnosed only by persistent presence of IgM antibody after 6 months

options.label: B
options.text: It’s the most common cause of non-syndromic sensory neural hearing loss

options.label: D
options.text: Mothers of developing countries who transmit the virus are usually symptomatic

questions.correct_answer: B. It’s the most common cause of non-syndromic sensory neural hearing loss
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • :
  • • Primary CMV infection occurs in 1% to 3% of pregnant women.
  • • It is estimated that 30% to 40% of foetuses of women with primary infection will become infected with CMV, and approximately 15% of these foetuses will develop significant disease.
  • • Infection during early gestation likely carries a higher risk of severe fetal disease.
  • • Maternal CMV tends to be asymptomatic and patients will rarely be diagnosed by clinical symptoms alone.
  • • CONGENITAL CMV INFECTION
  • • Among congenital infection
  • • 10% cases are symptomatic
  • • 90% cases are asymptomatic
  • • Severe multi organ disease is infrequent and occurs in less than 5% of infants with congenital CMV infections.
  • • Classical manifestations
  • • Classical manifestations
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly Petechial rashes Jaundice Microcephaly Intracranial calcification Neutropenia Laboratory Findings Direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevation of hepatic transaminases, CBC findings: Reduced platelets, anemia, Abnormal findings on cranial USG. CSF Analysis Elevation of mono-nuclear cells and protein levels in CSF
  • • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • • Petechial rashes
  • • Jaundice
  • • Microcephaly
  • • Intracranial calcification
  • • Neutropenia
  • • Laboratory Findings
  • • Direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevation of hepatic transaminases,
  • • CBC findings: Reduced platelets, anemia,
  • • Abnormal findings on cranial USG.
  • • CSF Analysis
  • • Elevation of mono-nuclear cells and protein levels in CSF
  • • Chorioretinitis is seen in some of the affected infants (<10%)
  • • Hearing loss is the most common long-term sequel of congenital CMW infection
  • • Diagnosis
  • • The diagnosis is made if CMV is identified in urine, saliva, blood, or respiratory secretions and defined as congenital infection if found within the first 2 weeks of life and as perinatal infection if after 4 weeks of life
  • • Spin-enhanced culture or “shell vial.”
  • • CMV antigen.
  • • CMV polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
  • • CMV IgG and IgM.
  • • Universal newborn hearing screening is recommended to detect hearing loss as early as possible.
  • • HEARING LOSS
  • • HEARING LOSS
  • • HEARING LOSS
  • • Genetic
  • • Genetic
  • • Genetic
  • • Approximately 50% of congenital hearing loss is thought to be of genetic origin, 70% recessive, 15% autosomal dominant and 15% with other types of genetic transmission
  • • Most common genetic cause of hearing loss is a mutation in the connexion 26(Cx26) gene, located on chromosome 13q11-12
  • • Approximately 30% of infants with hearing loss have other associated medical problems that are part of a syndrome (Alport, Pierre Robin, Usher, Waardenburg Syndrome, Trisomy 21)
  • • Nongenetic
  • • Nongenetic
  • • Nongenetic
  • • CMV is the most common cause of nonhereditary sensorineural hearing loss
  • • Persistence of IGg after six month is diagnostic.
  • • All babies born are not always symptomatic.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in fetal alcohol syndrome?

A 14-years-old infant had conjunctivitis, which later developed into respiratory distress and pneumonia. Chest X-ray showed bilateral lung infiltrates. Peripheral smear count showed 14,300/dl (N 43, L 54, E3). Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • NEONATAL CHLAMYDIA TRACHOMATIS INFECTION
  • • NEONATAL CHLAMYDIA TRACHOMATIS INFECTION
  • • Conjunctivitis
  • • Conjunctivitis
  • • Mothers with active untreated conjunctivitis transmits to approximately 30-50% of infants born
  • • Onset of symptoms – 5-14 days after delivery. In case of prolonged rupture of membranes the symptoms start earlier.
  • • Clinical Symptoms
  • • Mild conjunctival injection, mucoid to purulent discharge, chemosis, and rarely pseudomembrane formation
  • • Bleeds on taking a swab
  • • Pneumonia – seen in 10-20% of infants
  • • Pneumonia – seen in 10-20% of infants
  • • Onset 1-3 months of age; may occur as early as 10-15 days of life
  • • Persistent cough, tachypnea and absence of fever
  • • Auscultation – rales and wheeze
  • • The absence of fever and wheezing helps to distinguish C. trachomatis pneumonia from respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia ® a very important clinical differential diagnosis in older children
  • • The absence of fever and wheezing helps to distinguish C. trachomatis pneumonia from respiratory syncytial virus pneumonia
  • • ®
  • • a very important clinical differential diagnosis in older children
  • • Lab Findings
  • • Peripheral eosinophilia (<400 cells/ uL.)
  • • Chest X-ray – Hyperinflation accompanied by minimal interstitial or alveolar infiltrates.
  • • Treatment
  • • Erythromycin (50 mg/kg/day divided 4 times a day PO for 14 days)
  • • Azithromycin suspension (20 mg/kg/day once daily PO for 3 days).

questions.text: Which among the following is/are seen as an effect of hypoxic -ischemic injury in a neonate?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Umbilical artery blood pH is commonly below 7.0 Cerebral injury manifests as infarcts, HIE, tone abnormalities and seizure Asphyxial lung injury may manifest as RDS-like features, pulmonary hypertension and O2 requirement Subcutaneous fat necrosis and DIC may occur Adrenal haemorrhage can develop CVS may show ischemia, hypotension and regurgitation from tricuspid and mitral valves GIT perforation and NEC may develop Hypoglycemia and hypocalcemia are common in the first few hours of life
  • • Umbilical artery blood pH is commonly below 7.0
  • • Cerebral injury manifests as infarcts, HIE, tone abnormalities and seizure
  • • Asphyxial lung injury may manifest as RDS-like features, pulmonary hypertension and O2 requirement
  • • Subcutaneous fat necrosis and DIC may occur
  • • Adrenal haemorrhage can develop
  • • CVS may show ischemia, hypotension and regurgitation from tricuspid and mitral valves
  • • GIT perforation and NEC may develop
  • • Hypoglycemia and hypocalcemia are common in the first few hours of life

questions.text: Feature(s) of Crouzon syndrome may include?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Ref: Nelson 20th Ed, Forfar and Arneill Explanation: Crouzon syndrome • It is a genetic disorder due to mutation in FGFR-2 gene, characterized by the premature fusion of certain skull bones (craniosynostosis). • Signs and symptoms of Crouzon syndrome may include wide-set, bulging eyes; strabismus (misalignment of the eyes); a small, "beak-shaped" nose; and an underdeveloped upper jaw, with maxillary hypoplasia • Other features may include dental problems, hearing loss, and/or cleft lip and palate. The severity of signs and symptoms can vary among affected people, even within a family. • Intelligence is usually normal, but intellectual disability may be present • Digit abnormalities are absent

questions.text: Which among the following is/are good signs of attachment to the breast during breastfeeding by a baby?

options.label: B
options.text: Mouth of baby is wide open

options.label: C
options.text: Upper areola is more visible than lower

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Signs of effective attachment during breastfeeding • Chin firmly touches the breast • Mouth of baby is wide open • Lower lip of baby is curled outwards, ie everted • Upper areola more visible than lower • No pain on feeding • Cheeks stay rounded during feeding • Rhythmically sucks and swallows

questions.text: All among the following is/are metabolic causes of pediatric liver disease except?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Ref: OP Ghai 8th Ed, Nelson 20th Ed Explanation: Metabolic liver diseases in children • Conditions with hepatocellular necrosis: Wilson disease, hemochromatosis, galactosemia, tyrosinemia, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, reye’s syndrome • Conditions with cholestasis: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, Cystic fibrosis, Niemann-Pick disease, Byler’s disease • Conditions with abnormal storage: Gaucher disease, Glycogen storage disorders etc. Histiocytosis X, also known as Langerhans Cell histiocytosis is a monoclonal lymphoproliferative disorder, not a metabolic liver disease.

questions.text: Breast milk contains sufficient amounts of?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Ref: WHO breastfeeding guide Explanation: Remember that although protein in breast milk is less than animal milk, it is sufficient enough for the baby. Breast milk has high lactose, good micronutrients, including iron and Vitamin C. The three substances deficient in breast milk are Vitamin K, D and B1

questions.text: Cause(s) of congenital unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia may include?

options.label: E
options.text: Intravascular hemolysis secondary to fava beans in G6PD deficiency

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Ref: Nelson 20th Ed Explanation: Sepsis, Crigglernajar syndrome and Gilbert syndrome can all present with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in neonates and even in first 24 hr of life (the so-called congenital jaundice). Rotor syndrome produces conjugated jaundice hence not the answer. Hemolysis in response to oxidant stress (e.g. fava beans) in G6PD deficiency will not present in first 24 hr and hence will not be the answer.

questions.text: Craniosynostosis is associated with?
Clinical feature(s) of down syndrome child may include?

options.label: E
options.text: Downward slant of eyes medial to lateral

questions.text: Surgeries done in a child with tetralogy of fallot (TOF) may include?
True regarding Noonan syndrome is/are?

options.label: D
options.text: Wide carrying angle at the elbow

options.label: E
options.text: Less risk of congenital heart disease

questions.text: True about lanugo hair is/are?

options.label: B
options.text: Present more commonly in premature babies

questions.text: True regarding Wilms tumour is/are?

options.label: A
options.text: Diagnosed commonly in the neonatal period

options.label: E
options.text: Chemotherapy is not useful at any stage

questions.text: A child is born to a mother who is hepatitis B positive. What is the management to do for the baby?

options.label: A
options.text: Hepatitis B immunoglobulin at birth and vaccine at 3 months

options.label: B
options.text: Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine both immediately at birth

options.label: C
options.text: Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine both at 3 months

options.label: D
options.text: Hepatitis B vaccine at birth and immunoglobulin at 3 months

options.label: E
options.text: Hepatitis B immunoglobulin at birth and vaccine at 6 months

questions.correct_answer: B. Hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine both immediately at birth

questions.text: All are true about a child with Hypopigmented hair & mutation involving ATP7A gene ?

options.label: A
options.text: Also known as Menkes Kinky hair syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Copper and ceruloplasmin levels are elevated

options.label: E
options.text: Copper and histidine are useful in the management

questions.text: Which of the following fontanelle is last to fuse
A 6 kg child came with sunken eye, skin pinched going back I less than 2 seconds, irritable and drinking eagerly. What next step for management-

options.label: A
options.text: 30 ml ORS half hourly for two hours

options.label: D

questions.text: All of the following is true about ARDS except-

options.label: A
options.text: It occurs in first seven days of life

options.label: B
options.text: It shows severe pulmonary infiltrate with pulmonary edema

options.label: C
options.text: CPAP is required in its management

questions.correct_answer: A. It occurs in first seven days of life

questions.text: A new born with heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute came to paediatrician. What will be the first step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: PPV with oxygen at room concentration

options.label: C
options.text: PPV with 100% oxygen and chest compression

options.label: D
options.text: PPV with 100% oxygen and chest compression with epinephrine

questions.correct_answer: C. PPV with 100% oxygen and chest compression

questions.text: All of the following are characteristic of Rett syndrome except-

options.label: C
options.text: Abnormal dendritic morphology in cortical pyramidal cells

questions.text: MRP 2 is associated with which of the following?
